title: former-ross-high-pupil-ruari-paton-aiming-scottish-cup-glory
story: Ruari Paton will be hoping to line up for Stranraer todaywhen they make the long journey north to face Brora Rangers, who stunned Hearts in the previous round.The frontman attended the Tranent secondary school after signing for Hibernian as a teenager and making the move from Dublin.Many had expected Stranraer to be travelling to Tynecastle this weekend but Brora caused one of the biggest shocks in the competitionrsquos history when they won - last Tuesday.Paton was part of the Stranraer team taking on Brechin City at the same time and said that his reaction was much the same as football fans up and down the country when he heard the result.He said: ldquoI would not like to take anything away from Brora but you donrsquot really hear of a Championship team getting beaten by a Highland League or a Lowland League team ever.ldquoIt was a shock, it was a big shock, but fair play to them.ldquoWhat an achievement it is and it is an amazing challenge to overcome.ldquoYou cannot take anything away from them.Stranraer have enjoyed an impressive start to the campaign, with just one defeat since the beginning of November, as they look toto League One.Paton, who now lives in Bothwell, South Lanarkshire, has been at the heart of that form, scoring eight goals in all competitions, with strikes against Spartans and a last-minute penalty winner against Kelty Hearts in the previous round.He has also found the net for Gala Fairydean Rovers, while on loan from Hibs, and for East Kilbride in the competition last year.Now, attention has turned to the trip to Brora and Paton said: ldquoTherersquos nothing better in the world than scoring. Any forward player will tell you that. If you have a terrible game and score a goal or play fantastic and not score ndash you are judged on your goals as a forward.ldquoHopefully, I will get another goal but I need to make sure I am in the team. I would love another goal and I love the Scottish Cup. I loved it with East Kilbride and Gala Fairydean Rovers ndash it is great and you love those big moments in competitions.Paton moved from Dublin to East Lothian after signing for Hibs around his th birthday.He lived with Helen Leslie and her two sons, Darren and Jonathan, off Tranentrsquos Waterloo Road and attended Ross High School, where he studied physical education, English and sports leadership.The striker was quick to praise both the family and the school for helping him develop. He said: ldquoThey took me in asI was part of their family.ldquoThey were absolutely fantastic to me and made me feel so welcome.ldquoI went for dinner with them and they were brilliant.ldquoIn my first year, I spoke to Sean McPartlin, education and welfare officer, and he askedI wanted to do something. I agreed to it and they said I would train some days.ldquoIt is the best thing I ever did.That saw Paton ide his time between attending school and training at Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains on the outskirts of Ormiston.The -year-old spent two years at the secondary school and told Courier Sport how much he enjoyed the experience. He added: ldquoIt was brilliant ndash the best thing I ever did, honestly.ldquoI was not too keen going to school at that age with football andI had not then I would not have made many friends. The amount of people I met through school was unbelievable.Paul Reynolds, headteacher of the Tranent secondary school, said: ldquoNot only was Ruari a standout footballer, he was a true gentleman.ldquoHe was always extremely polite and his positive attitude was infectious. I have rarely met someone so filled with optimism.ldquoWith his lsquogo get lsquoemrsquo attitude, he settled into Ross High School very quickly and it was a pleasure to have him here. Irsquom delighted to hear that he is still playing and wish him all the very best.

title: driving-ban-musselburgh-man-caught-twice-drink-drive-limit
story: Stephen Baigan, of Stoneyhill Road, was breathalysed by police after being pulled over at Park Avenue, Edinburgh, on February  last year.The -year-old gave a reading of mg of alcohol in ml of breath. The legal limit is mg.Baigan admitted the offence at court on Monday.He was fined pound and banned from driving for  months.

title: final-approval-given-80-new-homes-edge-elphinstone
story: Eighty new homes to the west of the village were approved by members of the local authorityrsquos planning committee in December .Now, the plans have been signed off by the planning department, with ious technicalities ironed out.The scheme, which will be built between Tranent Road and the villagersquos football pitch, will see  new houses built alongside four flats.Highland Residential Developments Ltdrsquos proposals were unanimously approved by the planning committee a week before Christmas in .At that time, Labour councillors Fiona OrsquoDonnell and John McMillan were among those backing the plans.Twenty affordable homes will be built on the site, with East Lothian Council receiving pound, towards the provision of additional accommodation at the villagersquos primary school and Tranentrsquos Ross High School.A further pound, will go towards the refurbishment of the playing fieldrsquos changing pavilion, with more than a dozen parking spaces created within the development for people using the pitch, and nearly pound, will go towards play equipment in the park.The development will be accessed off the B, which passed through the heart of the village.All of the properties are two-storeys, with the housing split into  detached,  semi-detached and  terraced homes.The majority of the properties ndash  ndash will contain three bedrooms, with  containing two bedrooms and  containing four bedrooms.Each of the four flats will include two bedrooms.The development did not win favour with all residents though, with  objections to the proposals.Concerns included the number of houses was ldquocompletely out of character with the village setting while other fears included that the expansion of Tranent and Elphinstone was ldquodestroying the character of these settlements.

title: cafe-hairdresser-hollies-day-centre-musselburgh-reopening
story: Initially, the facilities will be open for three days, with the hairdresser open from .am to pm and the cafe opening its doors at am.The week after, they will open five days a week, at the same time.Liz Shannon, day centre manager, said: ldquoThe conditions are the same as before ndash entry is through the black gate on High Street. We have lsquotrack and tracersquo at the door as well as sanitiser. There have been changes put in place by the Government regarding track and trace so every inidual must be signed in. They should remember to have their phone number to hand.ldquoAll customers must wear a face covering until they sit at a table. Customers will leave by the front door, as before.ldquoCustomers for the hairdresser must use the chair lt in order to reduce the amount of sanitising to the building, for example the banister.ldquoThe cafe will be selling the usual menu, plus dinners.Liz said they were looking forward to reopening the centrersquos lunch club but added: ldquoWe are unable to open this until Government guidelines allow us to operate our bus.ldquoWe hope this will happen in the summer as we canrsquot wait to see all our members again.

title: new-community-orchard-created-musselburgh
story: A collection of  Scottish heritage apple saplings, some of the same ieties which were grown in an orchard at Pinkie House more than  years ago, have been planted in Lewisvale Park by Sustaining Musselburgh, a sub group of Musselburgh Area Partnership.Gaynor Allen, Sustaining Musselburgh chairperson, said: ldquoPlanting trees is a great way of investing in the future, it is good for the planet and good for the community.She added: ldquoPlanting apple trees will hopefully prove to have many more benefits, as it will provide free fruit, and we hope to engage with the whole community in an annual apple day once the trees are big enough to bear fruit.ldquoWe are very excited about this project and hope that schools and community groups will get involved.Musselburgh Area Partnership voted unanimously to support the project and hopes it will attract more people to Lewisvale Park.The partnership paid for  of the trees, which were planted by Andrew Hogarth, East Lothian Councilrsquos area amenities officer, and Tony Brunton, from the councilrsquos Musselburgh amenities team.Three of the trees in the orchard were donated by Art Walk Portyrsquos Neighbouring Orchard project, which gave out  trees for planting throughout Portobello, Musselburgh and Craigmillar.Iain Clark, Musselburgh Area Partnership chairman, said: ldquoMusselburgh Area Partnership is keen to support sustainability projects within our community.ldquoWith our new sustainability sub group and in partnership with our local amenity services, the planting of a new community orchard in Lewisvale Park will hopefully provide local focus on sustainable sources and provide the community with hopefully one of many natural resources.Over future years, Sustaining Musselburgh intends to add more fruit trees in the park and include pear, plum, hazelnut and walnut.Gaynor said: ldquoWe thought we would be lucky to begin with  trees, so we are delighted to have so many.ldquoWe intend to add more trees over the next few years.ldquoThis is a lovely project and we are delighted we were able to make it happen in the first year of Sustaining Musselburgh coming together.ldquoIt is fantastic to be a sub group of the area partnership and to work in partnership with other groups and organisations including Queen Margaret University.Sustaining Musselburgh is also working to get plastic free status for the town by encouraging organisations and people to get rid of single-use plastic, working with Musselburgh Active Toun, and working to bring a sustainability hub to the town.

title: longniddry-authors-book-delves-history-witchcraft-musselburgh
story: David Robertson, whose former research into the witchcraft of East Lothian was featured in his book Goodnight My Servants All, published in , found references in recently rediscovered trial records to th-century ldquoblack magic charms ndash which were actually pre-Reformation Christian prayers.David, , has combined the details of these previously unknown trials with other cases of Musselburgh witchcraft in his new book, A Calendar of Musselburgh Witchcraft.The Forthview Road resident said: ldquoThere were very few Musselburgh records in Register House, and they were supposed to have been lost, but a few years ago they were discovered in a locked room in the town hall in Musselburgh.ldquoThere was a real treasure trove of old burgh records, including two court books.The rediscovered records were moved to Haddingtonrsquos John Gray Centre, where David read through them to look for witchcraft trials.He found two cases, from , of young women named Jonet Little and Agnes Mitchell who were found guilty of witchcraft and sentenced to be strangled then burnt.David said: ldquoThat was the stock punishment for witchcraft. People run away with the idea that witches in Scotland were burnt alive but that is nonsense. They were strangled at the stake and then their corpse was burned.The records of their trial quoted the ldquodiabolic charms the women were said to have used ndash actually Catholic prayers.David said: ldquoThere were references to the Virgin Mary and to the saints and angels, which was not the sort of thing the new Protestant church in Scotland liked to hear about.ldquoThey thought these Catholic prayers were so beyond the pale they could be used to invoke the Devil. But I donrsquot think thatrsquos what the women who used them thought.But Davidrsquos book also seeks to point out that some of the women accused of witchcraft were not necessarily innocent of all crimes.He explained: ldquoObviously itrsquos a good thingpeople are trying to cure other people of illnesses and diseases, no matter how useless the cures may be.ldquoBut after all the research Irsquove done, I think at least some of these people were prepared to take on more dubious jobs.ldquoPeople would come to them for cures but sometimes people would come to them and ask to get rid of an unwanted husband or a sick child that had become a nuisance.ldquoWhile the majority of these professional healers was just what these women were, I do think there was at least the odd one that was prepared to take on a contract that was basically criminal.ldquoOne plant commonly used was foxglove leaves and the healer would use the phrase: lsquoThis will end or mend.rsquoA Calendar of Musselburgh Witchcraft is available via troubador bookshop history-politics-society a-calendar-of-musselburgh-witchcraft

title: plans-hold-creative-inventive-version-dunbar-civic-week-year
story: Many larger traditional community events usually held in East Lothian in the coming months have been cancelled or been scaled down due to the coronavirus pandemic.The volunteers behind Dunbar Civic Week have vowed that there will be celebrations this year, although there will no mass gatherings.This summer also marks  years since the first Dunbar Civic Week in .George Robertson, who chairs the Civic Week planning committee, said there would still be fun in the town in June.ldquoWe are keen for Civic Week to be a celebration of our wonderful community, he told the Courier.ldquoDunbar is a growing town and this is a great opportunity to welcome our newcomers to the fantastic things going on locally.ldquoThe children of the town have always been at the centre of Civic Week and, although there will be no Royal Court this year, we do hope that these competitions will provide our local families with the opportunity to celebrate lsquoThe Spirit of Dunbarrsquo and at the same time support our local businesses as we emerge from lockdown.The annual celebration will be on June - and feature a number of competitions.This yearrsquos event is on the theme of lsquoThe Spirit of Dunbarrsquo, with residents urged to be creative and mark out what makes the town special.Among competitions planned are: best dressed scarecrow best dressed house and best dressed window.A pound prize, in the form of vouchers for a local business, will go to the winner in each category, with pound for second place and pound for third.Plans are also being drawn up for a treasure hunt especially for youngsters, who will be challenged to seek out and identy particular items in the windows of High Street shops.Eileen Moore is pulling together the competition programme and anyone looking to get involved should email dunbarcivicweek@outlook. For more information, go to dunbarcivicweek.org.uk

title: speed-checks-carried-various-roads-haddington
story: Police have been using pop-up lsquoofficersrsquo at a iety of locations, including Haldane Avenue, West Road and Pencaitland Road, in a bid to influence driver behaviour.A spokesperson for Police Scotland said: ldquoThese have proven useful in deterring speeding and will be used in conjunction with real-time speed checks in the coming weeks.ldquoDrivers found to be exceeding the posted speed limit could be issued a fixed penalty ticket or reported to the Procurator Fiscal.

title: everything-need-know-scottish-parliament-election-2021-east-lothian-midlothian-north-musselburgh-constituencies
story: Here, you will find links to a series of articles telling you everything you need to know about the upcoming election.Voting informationPolling placesCandidatesConstituency candidates statements

title: scottish-election-manifesto-rundown-closer-look-partys-promises
story: But where do you start Weve had countless debates, soundbites, Twitter-bashing and more, and you wouldnt be blamed for struggling to wrap your head around it all.Thats why weve pulled together the key points from Scotlands main political partys manestos to help you ahead of Thursdays crucial vote.You can interact with each of the tables, searching by keywords like independence, economy, recovery and environment.

title: polling-station-scottish-election-2021-details-explained
story: The scale of ldquoSuper Thursday means that every voter in Great Britain will be able to take part in at least one type of poll, making it the biggest event of its kind outside a general election.How does the voting system work Scots will elect  MSPs, the outcome of which will give an indication of the level of support for the SNPrsquos push for a fresh referendum on independence.People will cast two ballots under the additional member system ndash a form of proportional representation ndash electing both constituency and regional MSPs.Votes for the inidual candidates in the  constituencies are counted first.The  regional MSPs ndash split across eight regions ndash are elected using a formula aimed at ensuring that the number of seats a party gets in total across a region is about the same as the percentage of votes it receives.And with more than . million people registered to vote in the upcoming Holyrood election, voters are now being encouraged to make sure theyre ready to vote on  May.The final total of voters registered for the Scottish Parliament election has been confirmed at ,, ndash the highest electorate ever for a Scottish Parliament election.You can find out where your local polling stationis by checking with your local council or by entering your postcodehere.Polling stations are open from am to pm onThursday May , .You must vote at your assigned polling station, however you dont need your poll card to vote.If you are registered to vote, but you dont have your poll card, you can go to the polling station and give them your name and address.In England, Wales and Scotland, you dont need any form of ID.However, in Northern Ireland, you must bring photo ID.Local election teams located at polling stations across the country will be doing everything they can to ensure polling stations aresafe for everyone.Certain safety measures will be in place in order to prevent the spread of Covid-, including the following:

title: scotland-staycation-ideas-guide-scottish-hebrides-lockdown-rules-ease
story: The newly relaxed rules ndash introduced on April  - allow travel across the country for socialising, recreation, or exercise.Yet it seems unlikely that Scots will be able to travel abroad any time soon, as strict self-isolation rules remain in place.But with a wealth of history, culture, and wildle to explore on your doorstep, staycations are the perfect way to spend this summer.Island hopping allows travellers to see some of the most untouched and scenic parts of the country.So, herersquos a small sample of what the Scottish Hebrides have to offer when the rules permit overnight stays.Barra is a small, tranquil island located in the most southern point of the Outer Hebrides.Itrsquos only eight miles long and four miles wide, with a population of about .Barrarsquos rich in beautul white sand beaches, wild grasslands, lochs, and panoramic views.It was recently ranked first as the most beautul island in Britain and has a distinct culture and fascinating history.The Heaval, Barrarsquos highest hill, stands at ft offering spectacular views of the island.Visitors can take a five-minute boat trip out to the Kisimul Castle, built around , which sits on a rocky island.Alternatively, you can walk on one of the islandrsquos five beaches, fish in one of the seven lochs, or explore some of the  cycle routes on offer.You can travel to Barra via ferry from Oban or Eriskay.Alternatively, you can travel by air from Glasgow or Benbecula.Flying to the island is very popular as the runway isnrsquot made out of tarmac but isnrsquot sand and sea.Barra Airport is unique as the only commercial airport in the world where scheduled flights use the beach as a runway.Plane arriving on the beach at Barra AirportAccommodation ranges from camping, to hostels, to hotels.Eigg is one of the most beautul community owned islands in the Inner Hebrides, situated about ten miles off the Scottish West coast.Itrsquos one of the smallest Hebridean Islandrsquos on the west coast at only five miles long and three miles wide.But what it lacks in size, it makes up in beauty and character.Eigg has a captivating history, untouched wildle, and a vibrant community.Visitors can canoe in the clear blue seas, watch eagles over stunning white beaches, cycle theof the island, explore the caves, or climb Britainrsquos largest pitchstone ridge.You can travel to Eigg on ferry from Mallaig or Arisaig, or on a sailing yacht with Selkie Explorers.Sunset from the ferryAccommodation on offer includes camping, glamping, yurts, cabins, and bothies.Islay is known as The Queen of the Hebrides and is the southernmost island in the Inner Hebrides, just north of Northern Ireland.Itrsquos the fth-largest island in the British Isles at  miles long and  miles wide, with just over , residents.Islay is known for its peaty, smoky whiskies and is home to nine working distilleries ndash which is celebrated in the Islay Festival.The festival will run from May  to June , transforming the island with traditional music, whisky tasting, ceilidhrsquos, Gaelic lessons, and golf.The islandrsquos dramatic landscapes are widely celebrated through art.Fair Isle You can reach Islay via plane from Glasgow or Oban.Alternatively, you can take the ferry from Kennacraig near the top of the Kintyre peninsula.Theresan array of hotels on offer for travellers to book in to.

title: 20-best-gardens-scotland-visit-post-lockdown-weekend
story: And where better to seek inspiration than in Scotlandrsquos gorgeous outdoor spaces  From castles with historic walled gardens to botanic idylls with their own microclimate and even contemporary sculpture parks, you might be surprised by the ersity found across the country.Whether you want to admire the rhododendrons in bloom at this time of year or you really miss the sight of palm trees, yoursquoll find no shortage of options to sate your inner botanist.pound entry If a garden can masquerade in Outlander as one belonging to the Palace of Versailles, you know itrsquos something special.Drummond Castle was likely selected as a shoot location in part because its formal Italianate garden was designed by Lewis Kennedy, who had worked for the Empress Joseacutephine at Malmaison in France.The striking parterres are distinctly Scottish, however, denoting the Drummond family coat of arms with traversing paths that centre on a stone obelisk sundial.Statues, urns and fountains add to its grand, palatial feel, neatly separated by ancient yew hedges. The castle isnrsquot open to the public, but yoursquoll be too bewitched by its grounds to care.drummondcastlegardenspound. entry The .-acre Victorian walled garden at Cambo Estate in Fe flowers with lilacs, rambling roses, elegant willows and naturalistic plantings that lend it a wild and romantic feel despite being carefully cultivated.Right now it is carpeted with tulips, and a visit later in summer will reward you with peonies. Cambo Burn runs through the garden ndash you can stop to admire it from the wrought-iron bridge ndash and therersquos even a burbling waterfall.Within the wider estate lies a winter garden and North American style prairie with tall grasses.Recent investment means the newly reopened Cambo Garden shop is now double the size with a wide iety of cut flowers, plants and gts for sale.cambogardens.org.ukFree entryHusband and we Hamish and Libs Martin were inspired by the novel The Secret Garden to create a sprawling green space on the outskirts of Edinburgh where people could absorb the beauty of nature.And so The Secret Herb Garden was born.The garden incorporates a herb nursery with more than  ieties the Secret Garden Distilleryand the Root to Market shop which sells garden-grown produce and items from local makers.Seasonal food is served in Fhior Garden Cafeacute, located in a plant-filled glasshouse. Distillery and gin garden tours will recommence on nd May.secretherbgardenpound entry With its dramatic clf-top location, Culzean Castle cuts an impressive figure.Itrsquos easy to be swept up in the majesty of the historic building, but donrsquot skip the opportunity to explore its magnicent grounds.Therersquos an th-century walled garden where fruit and vegetables grow, a Victorian orangery brimming with fragrant citrus trees, and  hectaresof mixed woodland with a coner plantation and swan pond.You may struggle to tear wee ones away from the Adventure Cove and Wild Woodland play parks ndash there are treehouses and zip slides ndash but when they get hungry therersquos the Home Farm Kitchen, currently takeaway-only.nts.org.uk visit places culzeanpound. entry Those missing foreign travel can get a taste of it via the plants and trees of Benmore, a satellite outpost of the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh.The garden, which benefits from a humid climate thanks to the Gulf Stream, is ided into geographical regions allowing visitors to get up close with monkey puzzle trees in the Chilean Rainforest, Huon pines in the Tasmanian Ridge and Japanese cedars in the Japanese Valley.Benmore is perhaps best known for its rhododendrons ndash there are more than , of them, and this is the best time of year to see them in full, colourful bloom.Therersquos also a Victorian fernery nestled in the hillside and home to many exotic species of feathery foliage.rbge.org.uk visit benmore-botanic-garden Honesty box donationYoursquod be forgiven for thinking yoursquod happened upon a Mad Hatterrsquos tea party when visiting Fingask.Surrealist topiary in irregular shapes and bold swirls cascade down the castle lawn, intermingled with stone globes, marble balls and a statue of Alice in Wonderland herself.The castle is private and can be hired for weddings and events, but visitors are welcome to wander the grounds in exchange for a donation to the honesty box in the corner of the car park.From there, follow the sign to St Peterrsquos Well. Positioned in a jungle-like area of the garden, this historic point of interest was once a th-century stop-off point for medieval pilgrims.fingaskcastlepound entry At more than  years old and spanning eight acres, the walled garden at Gordon Castle is one of Britainrsquos oldest and largest kitchen gardens.Its aesthetic is modern though owners Angus and Zara Gordon Lennox commissioned designer Anne Maynard to reimagine the space with her trademark bold, linear architecture.Six ornamental herbaceous borders frame the garden and inside therersquos a maze, a perfume garden, medicinal herbs, fruit trees, vegetable beds and a dipping pond surrounded by lavender.The gardenrsquos bounty is plated up in the cafeacute and utilised in many of the products for sale in the castle shop, from Gordon Castle gin, cider and ale to skincare, essential oils and candles.gordoncastlescotlandHonesty box donationWhile it would be a bit of a stretch to describe this public oasis in the heart of Glasgowrsquos Southside as a lsquosecretrsquo, there is still an element of surprise when entering the Hidden Gardens. Tucked away behind the post-industrial Tramway arts venue, the gardens offer tranquil escapism from the hustle and bustle of the city. Picnic under the Ginkgo tree, gather culinary inspiration from the herb and mint borders or read in idyllic solitude in the Xylotheque, a library of wooden books detailing dferent kinds of trees native to Scotland. Artwork is peppered throughout, including the newly launched Fly Away Home exhibition, on until the end of May.thehiddengardens.org.uk pound entry This award-winning sculpture garden on the -acreBonnington House estate near Wilkieston blends a lush landscape with contemporary, often whimsical, installations and exhibitions. Curated and run by Robert and Nicky Wilson, itrsquos like an open-air art gallery with the Pentlands as its backdrop. Next weekend will see the unveiling of an installation by Scottish artist Rachel Maclean, taking the form of an abandoned high-street shop amid the woodland. Other permanent works include Joana Vasconcelosrsquo Gateway, a pool garden crafted from more than , hand-painted Portuguese tiles, and Anthony Gormleyrsquos Firmament, a steel sculpture crouched in a field.jupiterartland.orgDonations acceptedThe warm microclimate of the Hebridean isle of Gigha allows sub-tropical species from Australia, New Zealand and Madeira to flourish in Achamore Gardens, created by Colonel James Horlick, a keen botanist, in the s. Its  acresare overseen by an all-female team currently tasked with revitalising the once world-famous garden, but even in its present condition therersquos plenty to admire. Jolly rhododendrons, delicate magnolia trees and fiery pink azaleas are all enlivening the grounds right now and an adventure through the bamboo maze will have you feeling like an intrepid explorer. Keep an ear out for the New Zealand Christmas Tree in the walled garden ndash its nectar brings all the bees to the yard.pound. entry The garden at Backhouse Rossie Estate is themed around art and science, reflecting the ownersrsquo backgrounds ndash one an artist, the other an engineer ndash and the fact their co-joined initials, CG and AT, are the same as the base pairs of DNA molecules. Two cobble-edged pathways shaped like a double helix run from either side to meet at a centrophere-shaped sculpture in the middle. Not science minded  Donrsquot worry: the garden is a joy from a purely aesthetic vantage, with a long archway festooned with white rambling roses, an orchard planted with apple and plum trees and a celestial-inspired grass labyrinth.backhouserossiepound entry You may have noticed dried floral arrangements have enjoyed a surge in popularity over the past year ndash sales have blossomed by % over the course of the pandemic. If itrsquos a trend you enjoy then perhaps yoursquoll be interested in visiting Priorwood Garden, which is set in Melrose Abbey and contains Scotlandrsquos only dedicated dried flower garden. Apple lovers will find more than  ieties growing in the old orchard, an ideal place to plonk for a picnic. Once yoursquove had your fill yoursquore in close proximity to both the abbey and Harmony Garden, a serene spot with scented borders,you fancy extending your visit.nts.org.uk visit places harmony-gardenFreeAberdeen regularly receives accolades for its public parks and gardens, which bring welcome splashes of green to the Granite City. Among the prettiest and most award-winning are Johnston Gardens, a short drive from the heart of the city. At just . acresthe space is easy to navigate and instils a sense of peace in all who stroll through it. Ducks glide on the iris-laced ponds and there are enough burns, waterfalls and rockeries to lull you into a  sense of countryside le. Make a stop on the rustic blue bridge for Instagram points.aberdeencity.gov.ukpound in the honesty boxIf itrsquos been a long time since you last set eyes on a palm tree, a trip to Wester Ross will reacquaint you with your best fronds. Warmed by the Gulf Stream, the lush and tropical gardens of Inverewe jostle with an array of plants from across the globe. Giant Calornian redwoods, Himalayan blue poppies and Tasmanian eucalyptus all thrive here and a network of walks throughout the garden ensure a bioerse feast for the senses. Wildle-spotting opportunities abound, too: red squirrels, red deer, otters, seals and golden eagles are often seen throughout the wider estate.nts.org.uk visit places inverewepound. entry The almost four-acrewalled garden at Crathes Castle is one of Scotlandrsquos finest. Sitting directly below the castle, it was largely designed in the early th century by Sir James Burnett and his we Sybil, who were heavily influenced by the soothing palettes and textures of the Arts and Crafts movement. The iety of plants and flowers on display is dizzying there are eight garden rooms, each with its own distinct look and feel. A fountain, Portuguese laurels and sculpted topiary dating to the s all add character, and therersquos a greenhouse containing a collection of Malmaison carnations .nts.org.uk visit places crathes-castlepound entry For a family day out, look no further than Ardkinglas. Kids will love hitting the Gruffalo trail, which weaves a path through the woods dotted with familiar characters and boards displaying pages from the book. At the end, near a lochan, is a sculpture of the Gruffalo. For grown-up bookworms, therersquos a scriptorium of tree-related poetry and prose from the likes of Voltaire and Spike Milligan in a timber gazebo in the woodland garden. Care more about seeing trees than reading about them  Yoursquore in the right place: among the impressive specimens at Ardkinglas are the Patagonian cypress, European silver fir and mountain hemlock.ardkinglaspound. entry The former home of Sir Walter Scott offers a rare example of a Regency garden, which the novelist designed in consultation with artist and architect friends. It is ided into three interconnecting outdoor rooms: the formal South Court, the sunken Morris garden and the walled garden, the latter of which is entered via a stone archway and contains fruit trees, herbaceous borders and a glass house. Many of the ingredients in its Ochiltreersquos Cafeacute are picked from the walled garden. Spring blooms include narcissi, camassia and puschkinia, and planning is underway for a new mindfulness garden with a water feature as part of celebrations for Sir Walter Scottrsquos th anniversary year.scottsabbotsfordFrom pound.Itrsquos hard to believe when looking at Glenwhanrsquos verdant landscape that its grounds comprised little more than boggy wasteland a few decades ago. Often lauded as Scotlandrsquos most beautul man-made garden, it has been designed around two lochans and has an arboretum with a trail consisting of more than  tree species, a rock garden and a -acremoorland walk through wildflowers, grasses and ferns. Head up to Tessrsquos Lookout for a viewpoint overlooking the gardens and beyond to the Isle of Man, Luce Bay and the Mull of Galloway. Andthe settingrsquos too idyllic for you to leave, thatrsquos fine: the Shepherdrsquos Hut in the garden sleeps two.glenwhangardenspound entry Painter Nicky Macpherson developed Attadale Gardens in the s after storms brought down many of its old trees. It was a chance to hit reset and has been designed with an artistrsquos eye think Monet-style bridges, sculptures, a giant sundial in the sunken garden and a geodesic dome housing one of Scotlandrsquos largest fern collections. A glossy lily pond, man-made waterfall and beds of bog-loving plants can be found in the Water Garden, and the Japanese Garden is a zen space with cloud-pruned azaleas, bamboo and miniature coners. Take a stroll along the rhododendron walk to reach a stone stairway that leads to a viewpoint with outstanding views of the Skye hills.attadalegardensPrice yet to be announcedOrdinarily this -acresculpture garden at Portrack House would be holding its annual open day this weekend, but this will now take place later in the year at a date yet to be announced. However, it would be remiss of us not to place it on your radar. An al-fresco work of art designed by the late landscape architect Charles Jencks and his we Maggie Keswick Jencks, it encompasses  areas exploring wonders of the cosmos. Stand-out features include a water cascade of steps symbolising the evolution of the universe and a terrace made of Astroturf and aluminium designed to show the distortion of space and time caused by a black hole.gardenofcosmicspeculation

title: plans-second-substation-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-lodged-council
story: The latest planning application, from Seagreen Wind Energy, shows a substation built on top of a former gasholder site stretching across paths which the firm admits may have to be erted.Seagreen sparked local concern when its initial consultation appeared to put the entire Greenhills in its proposed site.However, the plans now lodged with the council show the substation across the road from the former Cockenzie Power Stationrsquos main footprint on an old gasworks area now being used for a temporary car wash business.Acknowledging concerns raised by community councils over the loss of green space, Seagreenrsquos application says: ldquoAs far as possible, the proposed substationwill be sited to avoid any areas of habitat value. Where not possible, we confirm that any potential loss of woodland or scrub would be compensated for by post-construction landscape planting.And they added that any loss of existing footpaths was still to be discussedto agree how to mitigate it, adding: ldquoThis will likely involve a ersion to the existing footpath. If this is required, we will seek to minimise theof this ersion as far as possible.Seagreen currently has apoundbn offshore wind farm development under construction after it was granted exclusiverights for the Firth of Forth Zone of the UKrsquos Round  offshore wind farm development programme.Phase One within the zone includes the development of two offshore wind farms ndash Seagreen Alpha and Seagreen Bravo ndash located more than km from the Angus coastline.Work is already under way to bring the energy online at a number of sites, with Cockenzie the latest to be put forward.The former Cockenzie Power Station site was bought by East Lothian Council from ScottishPower after the stationrsquos iconic chimneys were demolished.It has been marketed by the local authority for projects, with a visionary masterplan setting out a wide range of employment, energy and recreational uses for the large -hectare site and surrounding area.To date, a substation which will bring energy onshore for Inch Cape Offshore Ltd is the only proposal given planning permissionfor the site.Seagreenrsquos proposals cover a nearby area of land outwith the power station footprint itself, including a beach car park next to it, where underground cables would be brought on land, under the main road and into the National Grid inshore.The proposal includes an onshore substation, underground electricity cables and ldquotemporary and permanent infrastructure to export electricity.

title: burnt-out-car-spotted-field-near-carberry
story: The Nissan Almera car was spotted by a member of the public in a field near the village this afternoon, with only a burned-out shell remaining.It is not currently known how the car got there, what happened to it andanyone was injured.The Courier has contacted Police Scotland and the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service for comment.

title: scottish-conservatives-leader-douglas-ross-campaigns-haddington-ahead-election
story: Mr Ross admired the view from the Nungate Bridge as he spoke of his optimism for his partys results, with the Scottish Parliament Election taking place tomorrow .And he joined Mr Hoy in delivering leaflets to residents in Gateside before heading across the country for a final push on the campaign trail.Mr Ross said: "It has been very strange not being able to do normal door knocking and we have had to adapt our methods. As restrictions have eased, we have been getting out a bit more and people have been really positive."I have a positive feeling about the election, we are a day away from the polls and people have a real opportunity to make a dference."

title: first-minister-nicola-sturgeon-makes-election-campaign-visit-prestonpans
story: The leader of the SNP popped by Prestonpans on Tuesday to help campaign for local candidate Paul McLennan, who is hoping to become East Lothians next MSP when voters go to the polls tomorrow .It follows Ms Sturgeon visiting North Berwick last Monday on the day coronavirus restrictions were relaxed.Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar also visited East Lothian on Tuesday, as did Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross today .The four candidates vying to succeed the retiring Iain Grayas East Lothians MSP are Euan Davidson , Craig Hoy , Paul McLennanand Martin Whitfield

title: dominos-confirms-opening-date-new-tranent-store
story: Planning permission for the shop, which is at  Bridge Street, was approved in  but Dominorsquos had kept tight-lipped on when it would open until now.The store has recently started advertising for staff. Those interested in a position in-store are asked to contact the recruitment team on  .The Courier can now reveal that the store will open on Monday, May .A total of  new jobs have been created, including pizza chefs, customer service colleagues and delivery drivers.Currently, East Lothianrsquos only Dominorsquos store is on Musselburghs North High Street.But with the opening of the Tranent venue, pizza lovers in the area will be able to enjoy firm Dominorsquos favourites, along with new innovations.And as well as being able to collect, delivery will be available to Haddington, something not available from the Musselburgh store.To celebrate the big day, there are going to be special promotions on opening week.Customers will be able to get  per cent off pizza when they spend pound or more or any pizza any size for pound. when collected.The offers run until May . People are told that the best way to make the most of the offers is to collect in store, order online, order via the Dominos app or call the store on  .And in recognition of Dominorsquos support for frontline workers, the store will also offer anyone with a valid NHS card a free small cheese and tomato or pepperoni pizza in-store until May .Palwindar Singh, area manager, said: ldquoWersquore excited to be opening a new store in Tranent to service new delivery addresses in the Haddington area, which will make it even easier for our loyal customers to get their hands on our fresh, piping-hot, homemade pizzas.ldquoWersquore also on the lookout for exceptional people to be part of our in-store team, including pizza chefs, customer service colleagues and delivery drivers.ldquoMore than four in five of our store managers start their own career out as team members. These roles offer a great opportunity for ambitious people looking to grow and build a career with the nationrsquos best-loved pizza company.

title: jobs-fair-marine-hotel-90-jobs-created
story: The Marine Hotel on Cromwell Road closed in January and is currently undergoing a major refurbishment.Much of the B-listed buildingrsquos interior will be completely revamped, including the entrance, lobby, reception, restaurant bar, spa and fitness centre. Its rooms are also undergoing redecoration works and are set to increase to more than .The hotel, which was bought from Macdonald Hotels in February last year by Adventurous JourneysCapital, is reopening to the public on July .Before that, it is hosting a recruitment fair on Tuesday, from noon until pm. A iety of jobs are on offer across a range of departments.Last November, the Courier revealed that  jobs were to go prior to the hotelrsquos closure, something that was described as ldquoprobably necessary at the time by hotel bosses.The recruitment fair will be an interactive event, conducted in a speed dating style format. The hotel is welcoming people to sign an application form on-site for an informal chat with the ious heads of department.Applicants are then invited to leave their CV for further assessment, ahead of being contacted later by the hotel, as well as right to work documentation.People are asked to wear a face covering and social distancing will be in place. Spaces can be booked by scanning a QR code, with those wanting more information but unable to attend the event asked to email careers@marinenorthberwick

title: regional-list-vote-counted
story: Every voter has two votesto elect candidates to the Scottish Parliament ndashthe constituency vote and the regional list vote.The constituency vote takes the form of a lilac coloured ballot and is where you vote for inidual politicians to represent your constituency. There are  constituencies in Scotland.The constituency vote is run on a first past the post system, which means whichever candidate wins the most votes in that constituency is elected to represent it in parliament. This system is used in General Elections for Westminster.The regional list vote will take the form of a peach coloured ballot andis more complicated to understand how your vote will count.There are eight regions in Scotland that eachseven MSPs. This means there are a total of  list MSPs in the Scottish Parliament.Theregions are:Central ScotlandGlasgowHighlands and IslandsLothianMid Scotland and FeNorth East ScotlandSouth ScotlandWest ScotlandEach region has between eight and  constituencies within it. Regardless of which constituency you are in, your peach ballot goes into the regional list vote pool.Each party will also have a ranked list of candidates for each region so as well as looking at who your constituency candidates are, its also a good idea to look at who is on your chosen partys regional list.The dHondt system of voting is a form of proportional representation that aims to ensureall voters are represented fairly.The system is named after Belgian mathematician Victor dHondt who first described the methodology in .First, all the peach ballots for the region are counted and the total number of ballots is ided by the number of seats each party has already won from that regions constituencies plus one.So, letrsquos say Party A wins all nine constituencies in Glasgow and also get , peach ballots in that region.Their total number of peach ballots is then ided by the number of seats already won plus one. , peach votes ided by   , votes.Letrsquos say Party B and Party Chave won , and , peach ballots from Glasgow respectively. As Party Ahave won every constituency seat, they are both currently on zero.As such, we need to ide their total number of votes by their seats wonplus one. So, , ided by one  ,, and , ided by one  ,.As Party B have the most votes of these three parties, they would win a list seat. The candidate elected would be taken from the top of the Party B list for this region.Now, the process is repeated. However, this time Party B have one seat.So, Party Asvote remains the same . Party C also remains the same , but Party Bs has changed.Their one seat means that their , list votes are now ided by one seat plus one. So, , ided by two  ,.Party C now have the most votes , so they win a list seat.Party Cs vote would then drop to , and the process is repeated five more times to complete the seven regional members elected to the Scottish Parliament.Along with the winners from each constituency, this means that each Scot is represented by eight MSPs.

title: east-lothian-council-disappointed-delays
story: East Lothian Council has expressed disappointment over a decision by the Reporter overseeing the appeal to allow developers Goldcrest to make a late submission based on a study which has no Scottish links.And in response to the decision, the local authority has told the Reporter it is unclear why the studyrsquos findings were only submitted in April when it was published in December last year.The council said: ldquoThe council is disappointed the appellant has made a late submission.ldquoLate submissions such as this lead to delays and can frustrate the local community.East Lothian Council refused planning permission for Goldcrestrsquos proposals for  residential and care units at Castleton Farm last August.One town GP compared the proposals to a ldquoghetto for older people, while a ground movement of local residents opposed to the plans swelled.Councillors ruled that the plans were ldquogrossly out of character as they refused planning permission.Goldcrest took their appeal to Scottish Ministers but, while the Reporterrsquos decision was due by April , a study by the Kingrsquos Fund on the Care and Support Specialised HousingFund, which does not operate in Scotland, was submitted by the appellants and accepted into evidence.The appellants, who have submitted  documents to the Reporter as part of the appeal, argued that while the UK GovernmentCASSH fund was not operating in Scotland, the findings of its impact were relevant.Among the findings reported were claims that extra-care housing models saved the NHS nearly pound, per resident over five years and reduced the number of days residents spent in hospital.Accepting the CASSH report into evidence, the Reporter extended the deadline for submissions to the appeal to allow the council to respond.In the local authorityrsquos response, it said much of the study was irrelevant to the appeal decisions, stressing again that the plans breached its policy to protect the countryside around North Berwick, adding it ldquowould cause signicant harm to the landscape and urging the Reporter to dismiss the appeal.A response was also received on behalf of Save North Berwick Views campaign insisting the CASSH study did not convince them ldquothat the benefits are of sufficient value or betterment that the development plan should be set aside in favour of the material consideration promoted by the appellant.Last August, when East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee unanimously rejected the plans for the care village, they heard evidence from objectors, including local GPDr Clare Doldon, who feared that residents of the new care project would be cut off from local services.She told a virtual meeting of the councilrsquos planning committee ldquoThis proposal has the potential to ghettoise this community, as it is too far to walk into the town.

title: elections-2021-cant-polling-station
story: A record number of people have already cast their ballots - with more than a million having registered to vote by post in Scotland.However, millions will stillheadto vote for their preferred party as the polling stations willstay open until pm on Thursday but undernew Covid guidelines.Many rules and regulations are already in place for when you go to vote so we have outlined what you need to know.Heres what you can and cannot do at the polling stationIf you have registered tovote you should have received a polling card in the post.This card will have yourpolling number and the address for where you cast your vote - your polling station.Alternatively, you can check here.To vote, you have to turn up at the polling station between : and : today.No, youdo not have to bring your polling card when you vote.However, this can speed up the process when you are there.If your card has not turned up and you do not know where your polling station is, you can contact your local authoritys election office.Yes, polling stations will be Covid safe.There will be extra signs, plastic screens, one-way systems, and hand sanitiser in place.Yes, everyone is asked to wear a face-covering inside the polling station.However, the Electoral Commission says no-one will be turned awaythey refuse to wear one.It is too late to apply for a postal vote.However, you can still apply for an emergency proxy vote.one of the following has happened since the deadline.Yes butyour name is identiable, your the vote will not count.Yes but you cannot take a picture of the ballot paper or you could get afine of up to pound,, or six months in prison.Voters are asked to bring their own pen or pencil, to keep the process as hygienic as possible.But some pencils should be available in the polling station, for those who forget.No, animals, apart from assistance dogs, are not usually allowed in polling stations.Yes, but campaigning inside polling stations is not permitted.Yes as long as you are notdisruptive.The Electoral Commission advises against this because it risks accidentally giving away how someone  voted.But people are welcome to share photos taken outside a polling station "to encourage your friends and family to vote".No, political discussion is banned inside polling stations.Staff will intervenethey hear any chat about candidates or parties.Bringing children to the polling station is encouraged, because it is seen as educating them about democracy.But a child is not allowed to mark your vote on the ballot paper.Some people deliberately spoil their vote - for example, by writing a message on the ballot paper as a protest.These are recorded but do not count for or against any candidate.No - it is entirely up to you whether or not you vote.Local councils recruit the presiding officer and staff to conduct the ballot, count the votes and process the postal votes.The first councils will be counted overnight into early Friday morning.But making the process Covid-secure means the results will probably take much longer than usual - possibly as late as Monday in some areas.The presiding officer can mark the paper for you, or a close adult family member or another eligible voter, such as a support worker, can accompany you.People with a visual impairment can request a device that lets them mark their own ballot paper. A large-print version should also be available.Polling stations are selected for accessibility. Buta voter cannot enter, the presiding officer may take the ballot paper to them.For help, call the Electoral Commission on   .

title: dave-berry-column-became-john-muirs-us-home
story: His birthplace in Dunbar does its best to spread the word, but the truth is he is better known and more revered in his adopted home of Calornia.Dunbar was a place of changes when he was born.With herring fishing and whaling booming, the Victoria Harbour was completed in , when he was four.In , the family emigrated to start a farm in the new state of Wisconsin, founded the previous year.Aged , he tried, but did not complete, university.While working in Indianapolis, an accident that almost blinded him changed his le for one of adventure.He began with a ,-mile trek to the Gulf Coast, then a voyage to Calornia, whose boundless ersity appealed to his soul.After several years of living wild in the Sierras, in , aged , he married the daughter of a fruit farmer in Martinez and settled to civilised le. . . although the call of the wild drew him back to his beloved mountains again and again.Because his house at  Alhambra Avenuewas the only one Muir ever really called home, Martinez is now twinned with Dunbar in one of the more curious examples of such connections.Sitting on the Carquinez Strait, where fresh waters of Suisun Bay merge with the salt of San Francisco Bay, Martinez is as old as Calornia itself, being on the road to the Gold Rush.When Muir was helping manage the orchards, the place was rural, with barely , inhabitants, at a time when Dunbar was over twice that size.But, even while Muir was still living there, things changed.A refinery opened in . By the time of his death in , there were three, and by the mid-th century, five.They are all along the shore of Suisun Bay, some distance from downtown, now the seat of Contra Costa County .In the last century, Martinez has become Falkirk-sizedndash four times the size of Dunbar.John Muirrsquos legacy in Americarsquos magnicent national parks and widespread environmental activism may be cited when COP comes to Glasgow later this year.Just what Muir would have thought of his adopted home becoming the Bay Arearsquos Grangemouth we will never know ndash but I suspectwe knew we couldnrsquot print it!

title: pop-legend-lulu-appearing-fringe-sea-east-lothian-summer
story: Singer Luluis set to appear at the annual festival on August  ndash  years after releasing her debut single Shout, which catapulted her to international fame at the age of .In , she was part of a four-way tie winner of that yearrsquos Eurovision Song Contest with her song Boom Bang-a-Bang, and in  she wowed young crowds when she appeared at the Glastonbury Festival.Also booked for Fringe by the Sea this year is perennial favourite Eddi Reader, former lead singer with Fairground Attraction who released her acclaimed solo album The Songs of Robert Burns in .Eddis to the North Berwick event for the fourth time on August .Comedy fans will get their fill at the festival with a mixed bill comprising Ed Byrne, Jo Caulfield and Larry Dean, with host Barry Castagnola, on August .Headliner Edhad a sell-out run at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in , while Jo had East Lothian audiences rolling in the aisles when she appeared at Fringe by the Sea in  and .Rory Steel, Fringe by the Sea director, said: ldquoTo have not one but two of Scotlandrsquos greatest female singers, as well as Ed Byrne, appear this year is such a coup.ldquoIt demonstrates how Fringe by the Sea has evolved from a small weekend festival in  to an event that attracts major acts to come and perform in North Berwick.Tickets for these shows will be available from am today .Fringe by the Sea, which runs from August  to  this year, has already booked a number of big-name acts including Basement Jaxx, Janey Godley, Huey Morgan, Peat  Diesel, The Blues Band, Irvine Welsh, Gail Porter and The Poozies.To address Covid rules and guidelines, the festival will make use of new spaces across the town, with outdoor auditoriumsenabling social distancing for audiences of up to  people.Visit fringebythesea for more details and to buy tickets.

title: dogs-polling-stations-uks-best-voting-day-tradition-explained
story: But enough of all that, election days in the UK have become about one thing and one thing only. Dogs at polling stations.Social media trend #Dogsatpollingstations has become a bit of voting day tradition in the UK.There isnrsquot much to it other than dog owners bring their dogs along when they cast their vote and post a picture of their canine friend exercising their democratic right outside of their local polling station.Dogs across the country are enjoying the extra exercise and it serves as a welcome break from politics for Brits until the polls close and all attention then turns to the count.Nobody really knows why it started but the tradition has really taken off since the  Brexit referendum and has become a bit of a phenomenon.Since then, Brits havehad quite a lot of voting to do.In , four-legged companions accompanied their humans to schools, village halls and pubs to vote in the European Parliament elections." alt"East Lothian Courier: Henry the labradoodle outside the polling station at Spike Island in Bristol " class"editor-image"Henry the labradoodle outside the polling station at Spike Island in Bristol " alt"East Lothian Courier: Golden retriever Riloh with her owner Natasha Collins-Daniel in Bristol " class"editor-image"Golden retriever Riloh with her owner Natasha Collins-Daniel in Bristol " alt"East Lothian Courier: A caravan polling station on a farm in Garthorpe, near Melton Mowbray " class"editor-image"A caravan polling station on a farm in Garthorpe, near Melton Mowbray In December ,Dogs at polling stations were out in force as voters took their canine friends to join in the democratic process.Members of the electorate honoured the December election by putting a festive spin on the tradition." alt"East Lothian Courier: Dogs turned up in festive outfits in December . " class"editor-image"Dogs turned up in festive outfits in December . The tradition has caught on in Australia and America.AsAmericans flocked to the polls to cast their votes in the Presidential election, some were accompanied by their pets." alt"East Lothian Courier: Dogs joined their owners for the presidential elections in the US last year. " class"editor-image"Dogs joined their owners for the presidential elections in the US last year. Keeping up with tradition, pups across the UK have joined their owners for Super Thursday todayin the largest test of political opinion outside a general election, with the future of the Labour Party and the state of the Union among the issues at play.Hereare a few of the best pictures posted:Fantastic turnout in Dulwich Village! #dogsatpollingstations #superthursday #londonmayor pic ytpUdjIt isnrsquot that Buster isnrsquot interested in democracy, itrsquos just that he doesnrsquot usually get out of bed before lunchtime#dogsatpollingstations pic gXBjFcKfyCLondon: This election is going down to the wire and we cannot be complacent - every vote counts.Polls are open and you have until pm.A vote for Labour is a vote for London. If you love our city please come out and vote for it! #votelabour #dogsatpollingstations pic KXhDCsxJDXTaking your pooch to the polls You know the drill, send us your pics! # #DogsAtPollingStationsHerersquos Max to show you how itrsquos done: pic jXJvqIvSFirst time voting as a dog owner so obligatory #dogsatpollingstations pic. pic cavTarIJzn

title: covid-nails-lines-nails-mean-covid
story: Professor Tim Spector has said that people may notice changes to their fingernails after a Covid infection.Professor Spector, who is the principal investigator of the Zoe Covid Symptom Study app, said that the dference can happen evenyou did not experience any other symptoms of Covid-.Herersquos what you need to know:Professor Spector noted that people who have a "clear line", which creates a prominent ridge, growing out of the nail may have had Covid before.People may also notice discoloration under their nailsthey have previously had the virus.The professor said it is recognised as the nails recover after an infection. However, he adds that these are usually harmless and can be caused by any illness - meaning it is not only linked to Covid-.Do your nails look odd  COVID nails are increasingly being recognised as the nails recover after infection and the growth recovers leaving a clear line. Can occur without skin rashes and appears harmless pic QLfdrcDcWriting on Twitter, Prof Spector said: "Do your nails look odd  COVID nails are increasingly being recognised as the nails recover after infection and the growth recovers leaving a clear line. Can occur without skin rashes and appears harmless."Several Twitter users responded to the post stating they had experienced this symptom after being unwell.Julie McGlue replied: "Myself  my husband had covid last September  we noticed we had grooves in our nails too"User pippabrunton said: "I noticed this and also hair loss  months after covid"Drizzydre wrote: "Ok but I % had nails that looked like this in March  and thatrsquos cause everyone in the show I was in in February  probably had Covid but it was before testing was a common thing but this is more proof that we actually did have it!!!!!!!!!!!"These horizontal grooves appear on the nail after an infection and are known as Beaursquos lines.The lines are commonly found in patients who have had a viral illness. This is due to the stress that their body was under battling the virus.These have been reported among people who have experienced Covid toes or fingers when the skin has become discoloured.The lines will eventually grow out over time.Dr Tanya Bleiker, president of the British Association of Dermatologists, explained: "Dermatologists are seeing Covid Nails in some patients who have had an infection with SARS-CoV-, the virus responsible for Covid .These changes have long been recognised as Beaus lines and are transverse indents in the nail of many, or all, fingernails and sometimes toenails."They are caused by a temporary interruption of the growth of the nail due to a number of causes including febrile illnesses such as Covid- infection."These indents tend to appear two to three weeks after the illness - longer in toenails."They are harmless and grow out with time - often surprisingly a few months."

title: brunton-musselburgh-reopen-month
story: Audiences will be welcomed back to Venue  from May  as the team works to programme a range of theatre and concert screenings, with singing stars Michael Ball and Alfie Boe on screen on July  and co-founder of the band Fleetwood Mac, Mick Fleetwood and Friends, confirmed for September .Movie highlights get under way with Nomadland on May , Ammonite on June  and Minari on June .In line with Scottish Government regulations, The Brunton has a range of modications in place including signage, floor markings, sanitiser stations, enhanced cleaning schedules, face coverings, reduced capacity in the auditorium and advance booking only. Staff will be on hand to offer a warm welcome and answer any questions visitors have.The trust will continue to follow Scottish Government guidance and hopes to be able to resume live performances in the not-too-distant future as restrictions ease.Michael Stitt, chairman of The Brunton Theatre Trust, said: ldquoWe are delighted to finally be opening our doors again to welcome back our audiences from the local community and beyond.ldquoWorking with East Lothian Council, we have taken considerable steps to ensure a Covid-safe environment within our much-loved venue.ldquoCareful consideration will be given to the type of programming that we hope will be possible in the coming months, with the safety of our audiences and staff at the forefront of our artistic decision-making whilst always adhering to Scottish Government guidelines.Donations of any size are welcomed to help The Brunton continue to bring a programme of arts and entertainment to East Lothian and beyond.Financial contributions can be made via The Bruntonrsquos website thebruntonFull details of the cinema programme can be found on The Bruntonrsquos website.Further details about enhanced protocols and online ticket booking are also available at the venuersquos website.

title: 600-000-funding-pot-east-lothian-council-help-county-recover-pandemic
story: The money, from East Lothian Council, also aims to be a shot in the arm for the countyrsquos tourism and hospitality sectors and its town centres.Michaela Sullivan, the councilrsquos head of service development, welcomed the funding, saying: ldquoItrsquos an important part of our essential, ongoing work to support businesses as we recover from the Covid- pandemic.ldquoThis support funding has been designed to meet the needs of existing industry, pave the way for new job creation and to ensure our workforce is ready with the right skills.ldquoIt also looks at how we build on East Lothian as a destination and allows us to target key markets to grow our short and longer-term tourism industry.The largest sum of money ndash pound, ndash will be used to support the tourism and hospitality sector, including a grant scheme to support projects support for marketing and the Visit East Lothian website and funding of a project to study and manage the movements of visitors to East Lothianrsquos coast.A further pound, will go towards supporting businesses, safeguarding employment and encouraging growth, including pound, grants to support job creation and the buying-in of expert support for business growth.There is funding of pound, for town centre recovery and renewal, including a potential expansion of the East Lothian Gt Card scheme targeted funding for tradersrsquo groups and projects and the potential expansion of a digital high street project to give traders a greater online presence, with a further pound, to support the rural economy, including a food festival, funding to promote digital connectivity and support to re-open rural toilet facilities.Finally, pound, will be used to support employability, including a careers event and vocational hospitality training, and pound, to support Love East Lothian messaging, including a potential newsletter to all East Lothian residents to promote local businesses with support from an online campaign.

title: scottish-election-declaration-times-results---what-expect-today
story: Votes in some  of the  constituency seats will be counted from about am on Friday, with the first results expected from noon.It is anticipated all  should be declared by Friday evening.Then, from about am on Saturday, the remaining  constituency seats will be counted, after which the regional seats will be allocated.Due to the Covid- pandemic, there is a staggered tallying up of ballots for the  Holyrood election, with all results expected to be declared by Saturday evening.Normally, counting begins immediately after the polls close at pm and continues overnight, with results confirmed in the early hours.But the need for social distancing among count staff has meant votes will be tallied from Friday.This yearrsquos election, while conducted under the constraints of coronavirus rules, is also considered to be one of the most important since the Scottish Parliament opened in .With the SNP set for another five years in government, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon will no doubt ramp up the pressure on Westminster to grant the powers for another vote on Scottish independence.Her opponents in the Tory, Labour and Liberal Democrat parties have stressed the importance of focusing on Scotlandrsquos recovery from coronavirus insteadBut the SNP leader and her party have said no referendum will be held until after the immediate health crisis is over, and they insist powers gained through independence would actually improve the recovery in Scotland.Ms Sturgeon has said another pro-independence majority in the Scottish Parliament, including the Greens and Alba Party seats, should be enough to let Scots vote again on whether they want to leave the UK.Take a look at the potential declaration times here:

title: burgh-primary-school-pupils-images-make-people-smile-bid-raise-money-playground-improvements
story: Pupils from  classes took part in a competition on the theme lsquoSomething That Makes You Smilersquo during the Easter holidays to produce photos for a school calendar which will be sold in aid of the playground project.Avril Campbell, reporter for the Musselburgh Courier, had the tough task of choosing winners on an anonymous basis and the results were announced at school assembly last Friday.The overall winner was lsquoSunset In The Harbourrsquo, by Romilly Upcraft, P, which will appear on the front page of the Burgh Primary  calendar.The other winners were: lsquoBarbies and My Friend Jackrsquo by Clara Bose, nursery lsquoThere Are Eggs Under There!rsquo by Anna Thomson, P lsquoDaffodil Picturersquo by Vinnie Dunn, P lsquoEtta In The Parkrsquo by Lily Doherty, P lsquoI Love Ice Creamrsquo by Caroline McDonough, P  lsquoPeek A Baarsquo by Ava Virlogeux, P lsquoBassie The Guillemotrsquo by Ophelia Carter, P  lsquoHeidirsquo by Lily Fisher, P lsquoSpring Bunniesrsquo by Erica Olds, P  lsquoBooks Hearts and Flowersrsquo by Anya Peet, P lsquoWinter Wonderlandrsquo by Angus Ross, P and lsquoThe Bridges rsquo by Lauren Hollingsworth, P.Avril said: ldquoIt was a very dficult decision as the standard was very high and the pupils were so imaginative with their subjects.S Luca of Musselburgh kindly donated chocolate treats for all the children who entered the competition.Jon Doyle, headteacher, said: ldquoOur all-weather pitch no longer has adequate goals, our adventure log-trail is intermittently closed due to disrepair and, vitally, surfaces and facilities need to be made safe and accessible for our wheelchair users.ldquoWe value the support of our parent council in working with us to make our playground area everything it can be for our children and community.The parent council has also organised other fundraising initiatives, including Easyfundraising, a school lottery and a local scavenger hunt.

Labour had dominated the Scottish Parliament elections in East Lothian since the constituency was created in .Iain Gray has been the countyrsquos MSP for more than a decade but announced he was stepping down from the role earlier this year.Labour had hoped that former MP for East Lothian Martin Whitfield could follow in his footsteps and ensure the party continued its grip on the seat.However, Mr McLennan won by more than , votes from the Labour candidate, with the results announced at Meadowmill, near Tranent, earlier this afternoon .The newly elected MSP said: ldquoI want to give special thanks to Iain.ldquoHe has been MSP for a long time, mostly here in East Lothian, and Iainrsquos presence will be missed in East Lothian.ldquoI want to thank my fellow candidates ndash Craig , Euanand Martin .ldquoIt has been a very dferent campaign and probably the first time we have seen each other since the virtual hustings.Mr Gray and Mr Whitfield were among the first to congratulate Mr McLennan, who is also a councillor for the Dunbar and East Linton ward on East Lothian Council, on the victory.The result was the first seat to change hands today .Mr McLennan secured , votes , with Mr Whitfield in second spot on , .Haddington and Lammermuir ward councillor Craig Hoyfinished in third with , votes , with the Liberal Democratsrsquo Euan Davidson in fourth with , votes .The result gives Mr McLennan a majority of , ndash the biggest majority in the county since .He described the victory as ldquoprobably the most humbling thing in my le and said: ldquoIrsquove lived in East Lothian all my le.ldquoIt is the most fantastic county, it is the best county, and I am incredibly humbled to represent it.ldquoMy pledge is to work with all groups in East Lothian and to work with all political parties in East Lothian because that is incredibly important.Mr Whitfield served as the countyrsquos MP from  to  but could not secure the Holyrood seat.He spoke to the Courier shortly after the results were announced and said: "Im very disappointed."It was very close and at the end of the day it has been a very, very strange election."All of the little evidence and things that we look for were unavailable this time and we were unable to knock on lots and lots of doors and speak to people, which has always been a very positive campaign strategy for Labour."The teacher at Dirleton Primary School echoed the comments of Mr McLennan in paying tribute to Mr Gray.He described him as a "phenomenal MSP" and was saddened he was "unable to carry the baton forward".He added: "East Lothian is a stunningly beautul place."The people here are massively important and I know that Paul will serve them very well and remember it is the constituents here that elected him."Mr Hoy also paid tribute to Mr Gray, who became the countys MSP in .He said: ldquoI hope that those who follow will rise to the level of service set by Iain.The Conservative share of the vote was down just over three per cent on the results from , when Rachael Hamilton also finished third.Mr Hoy added: ldquoWe fought a very positive campaign, a good campaign, very well run, but we could not get round the simple observation that it was a Labour-held seat and we were in third position.Mr Davidson felt the Liberal Democrats had been ldquosqueezed between the top parties.However, he was hopeful the party would enjoy more success through the regional vote, with the results yet to be announced.A total of , votes were cast, which is a . per cent turnout.A total of  votes were rejected, with five voting for more than one candidate and the remainder unmarked or void for uncertainty.

title: mary-contini-column-tackling-child-poverty-must-new-governments-first-priority
story: After an initial complication of paperwork and hold-ups, in some trades things are trundling along not very dferent than before.The cost of importing has increased substantially but the value of Sterling has also increased, mitigating some of the losses.Other businesses have fared worse. Export of fresh farm foods and seafood has suffered a heavy impact which has not yet been resolved.However, there is a glimmer of a silver lining: a stronger home market has emerged. With Covid restrictions, people are cooking more at home and searching out the best ingredients.As the staycation market booms, UK visitors will look to experience the best of Scotland. Our hotels and restaurants have risen to the challenge and are spruced up ready to welcome us. Menus are brimming with Scottish produce, so much from East Lothian.Seafood that was once exported to the continent is now freshly delivered direct from boat to table. Lobsters, langoustine and scallops as big as Tunnockrsquos tea cakes Scotch beef marbled and aged, and new-season spring lamb asparagus, spring greens, strawberries, the list is impressive.No wonder so many European tourists want to visit. They appreciate us more than we do ourselves!But with all this abundance of excellence, we have a guilty, shocking secret. One in four of our children has no access to this abundant food and are living in food poverty.Foodbanks are everywhere, feeding families who are forced to queue for help. How can this be happening in our fertile country  What has gone wrong Therefore, whomever forms the next government must address the shame of our child poverty as the first priority. Only then can we ask to be recognised as the best small country in the world.
