title: scottish-election-2021-results-full-holyrood-vote
story: The SNP won  seats in the election after the polls closed on Thursday. The figure marked one short of a majority, but one more than they won back in .The Heralds live Covid tracker brought the results straight to you as they came in, and now weve had the chance to lay them out in full and look at how theyve changed in the last five years.The map below gives a straight forward look at who won the election. The largely yellow-painted regions give a good indication that the SNP took home the victory, however fell just one seat short of that crucial , which would have meant they would have had a majority.If we look at this map in comparison with the map in  by clicking the blue button above, we can see that a few seats changed hands.Notably, the SNP won in Ayr. This seathad been held by the Conservatives John Scott almost since the start of the Scottish Parliament, but was won on Saturday by Siobhan Brown.Take a look at the constituency vote share.We can compare this years vote share to that in , and see how this has changed.Weve also pulled together a comprehensive list of all the winning parties by constituency, and given them a side-by-side comparison of the winners back in .The list votes saw parties like Scottish Labour, Scottish Conservatives and Scottish Greens pick up seats.The map below shows where these seats were gained. To view the results in smaller regions, simply zoom into the area you wish to see for the split of regional votes.Weve also listed these out in full in our interactive database. If you want to view your local region, or look for a specic party, pop it into the search bar.And just like the constituencies, weve taken a look at the vote share and compared it to  to give us a concrete look athow its changed overtime.

title: time-queens-speech-watch-can-expect
story: It will be the first public ceremonial duty the Queen has carried out since the death of the Duke of Edinburgh, and her first public appearance since her husbands funeral.Charles, The Prince of Wales, will be at the event as he has for the last  openings.What time is the Queens speech The key aspects of Queens Speech ceremony will take place between am and .pm on Tuesday, May .What impact is Covid having on the Queens speech MPs and members of the House of Lords will have to wear masks throughout unless they are exempt, and everyone present will have to take a Covid test beforehand and only be allowed to attendthey have a negative result.Signicantly fewer politicians and peers will be there compared with previous years and no diplomatic or non-parliamentary guests have been invited, with just  people attending including the Queen.There will  people in the chamber, including the monarch, Charles, Camilla, the Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle, Prime Minister Boris Johnson and leader of the Opposition Sir Keir Starmer, representatives from the House of Lords and House of Commons and those involved in the ceremonial procession.There will also be  members of the Lords and  MPs in the Royal Gallery.There will be no military street liners or lining of the Sovereignrsquos staircase and no military band nor Guard of Honour outside the Palace of Westminster or as part of the procession from Buckingham Palace.Who is Black Rod Black Rod is responsible for controlling access to parliament and maintaining order.Sarah Clarke, Lady Usher of the Black Rod, will see the doors to the Commons shut in her face as she arrives to summon MPs.She has to strike the door three times before it is opened.It is a practice that dates back to the Civil War and is said to symbolise the Commonsrsquo independence from the monarchy.

title: coronavirus-scotland-scots-urged-be-vigilant-restrictions-set-ease
story: The First Minister is holding a Covid briefing tomorrowto announce the ldquonext easing of restrictions scheduled for May .The UKrsquos four chief medical officers have said the threat level should be lowered, thanks to the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.The joint statement said: ldquoFollowing advice from the Joint Biosecurity Centre and in the light of the most recent data, the UK chief medical officers and NHS England national medical director agree that the UK alert level should move from level  to level .ldquoThanks to the efforts of the UK public in social distancing and the impact we are starting to see from the vaccination programme, case numbers, deaths and Covid hospital pressures have fallen consistently.:Covid Vaccine: More than  per cent of over-s in Scotland have had both dosesldquoHowever Covid is still circulating with people catching and spreading the virus every day so we all need to continue to be vigilant. This remains a major pandemic globally.Smith warns Covid- remains a global pandemic. PA: CreditldquoIt is very important that we all continue to follow the guidance closely and everyone gets both doses of the vaccine when they are offered it.The Scottish Government has been gradually easing lockdown restrictions, with stay home rules lted at the beginning of April.From May  pubs can sell alcohol in doors and cinemas, theatres, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls can open.:Coronavirus Scotland:  new Covid cases in  hours and no new deathsAdditionally, four people from two households will be able to socialise indoors in a private home.Scotland has recorded  new cases of Covid in the past  hours, with people in hospital yesterday after recently having tested positive for the virus.Only one death has been recorded in the last week and the test positivity rate has consistently been recorded at slightly above or below one.The coronavirus death toll, among those who tested positive in the previous  days, remains at . However, registry offices are generally closed at weekends.So far, ,, people have received their first dose of a Covid- vaccination and ,, have received their second dose.More than % of adults aged  and over in Scotland have now had both vaccines.However, NHS Grampian has been battling an outbreak in Moray, by offering vaccinations to those aged - and increasing testing in an effort to control a rise in cases.

title: scottish-parliament-designed-return-majority
story: Despite their success in the polls, many, such as Michael Gove, highlighted the lack of a majority as a failure to secure a second independence referendum with Nicola Sturgeon responding saying that independence should be a ldquomatter of when ndash not .The SNP saw an increase in the number of seats from the previous parliament and a record share of the voteamid an increased turnout, with the pro-Scottish independence Greens also increased their number of seats from  to , thus giving the Scottish Parliament a lsquopro-independencemajority.But does the Scottish Parliament provide a majority, and does the SNP missing out on a majority limit any potential calls for a referendum :Scottish election : Results in full from Holyrood voteIs the Scottish voting system designed for majority governments One of the main dferences between the Scottish Parliament and the voting system is that it is not necessarily designed toa majority government.Unlike Westminster, the Scottish voting system was introduced to make it more dficult for parties to have an overall majority and to encourage parties working together in coalition or lsquoking-maker governments.This can be shown from looking at the elections even prior to the SNP dominance. In the  and  elections, the Labour Party won the most seats and obtained the most votes, but they did not get an overall majority as a result of the voting system. Indeed, in the history of the Scottish Parliament, Scottish elections have only ed a majority once, when the SNP effectively broke the mould in .Scotland is ided into  constituencies and each constituency elects one MSP. The way that this MSP is elected is the exact same method as elections in Westminster - using First Past The Post .The Additional Member System , based on the German mixed-member proportionalsystem, is used in Scotland and is signicantly more proportional than FPTP. Such an election system is known as a hybrid electoral system. AMS means that the overall number of MSPs elected for each party is roughly proportional to their electoral support.The second vote is used to elect  additional members that will complete the political landscape of Holyrood. Scotland is ided into  parliamentary regions and each region elects  regional MSPs.DHondt method in Scotlandrsquos Additional Member SystemRegions are elected by proportional list via the DrsquoHondt formula.Scotlandrsquos system is designed to limit the winning party using the DHondt method in the additional member system. It is sometimes described as the highest average method. The principle of this idea is that a partys vote total is ided by a certain figure which increases as it wins more seats. Thus, as the party becomes bigger in the parliament, the partys total in succeeding rounds gets smaller, allowing parties with lower initial totals to win seats and effectively make establishing a majority much harder.In Scotland, the list vote is ided into the number of constituency wins in the region +. This means that by winning more constituencies, you need a signicantly larger list vote.In simple terms, the more constituency seats a party wins, the fewer list seats it will win.:Gordon Brown launches pro-Union campaign aimed at middle ScotlandA proportional system The Scottish Parliament typically works in a proportional way using the DrsquoHondt system, with the share of the votes aiming to closely mirror the share of the vote. And it has been relatively successful in doing this once again in .The SNP obtained just under half of the vote, and has just under half of the available seats. The Scottish Conservatives, who campaigned on the List vote, or peach vote mainly, secured .% of the vote and won % of the seats. Labour had a list voteof % of the regional vote - which translated into % of the seats. The Scottish Greens won % of the vote and obtained % of the available seats in the chamber.SNP fall one seat short of an overall majority in Scotlandrsquos parliamentary elections - in a system designed to make majorities all but impossible - but with the Greensrsquo  seats, a clear majority of MSPs are in favour of Scottish independence pic lneEcBdXAThe list vote is arguably a better indicator for proportion of the parliament given the increase in tactical voting at a constituency level, with voters effectively lsquolending their votersquo to the party with the best chance of stopping the SNP.In  the SNP won a majority for the first and only time so far in Scottish Parliament history through losing out on more constituency votes but being propped up by regional votes. The party won  of seats at a constituency level but a high regional vote saw them obtain  list seats.  years on they have upped their constituency wins to  but only picked up  regional seats as a result.Do Westminster Governmentrsquosmajorities General elections are exceptionally likely tomajorities for one party, but once again this is due mainly to the voting system and not due to the percentage of the vote.For example in the  General Election, the Conservatives won a majority and a mandate for Brexit with .% of the vote - however as the system was less proportional they obtained % of the seats in parliament.To further simply, the majority voted against the party which won the election and ended up with the majority in the House of Commons.Does a majority indicate a mandate for independence The constitutional battle raised by the Scottish election is one for the politicians to argue over - however, early indications seem to imply that Westminster will rely on the constituency majority backing the union and the failure to secure a majority to oppose Indyref.Judging the Scotland results by whether @theSNP wins a majorityseems a rather unionist prism. Scotland looks set to have clearly voted for an even more pro-independence parliament than before.In a host of interviews over the weekend, Michael Gove said the failure to secure a majority meant that the UK Government was not considering a second independence referendum. He said ldquoThe majority of people who voted in the constituencies voted for parties that were opposed to a referendum with the SNP obtaining .% and Scottish Greens obtaining .%."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Michael Gove: Scottish independence referendum would be a massive distraction","description": "Michael Gove: Scottish independence referendum would be a massive distraction","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media RyJPmQ poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests RyJPmQ.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Looking at the regional vote share, while the SNPrsquos list vote fell by .% to .%, the Scottish Greens obtained .% and Alba obtained .% givingpro-independence parties a .%at the regional list level.Many critics have also pointed out that the Conservatives used the  election as their mandate for Brexit but secured less than half the vote. Indeed over % of the population voted for pro-European parties.Others have pointed out that in a parliament designed to prevent majorities, a majority of pro-independence parties have been ed by the Scottish people.

title: covid-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-update----watch-expect
story: The First Minister, whois to address the nation on Tuesday, is expected to confirm and outline furtherdetails of how and when restrictions can be lted acrossScotland.It isthought thatMs Sturgeon will confirm changes scheduled to go ahead from Mayunder Level  of the framework - includingup to four people from two households socialising indoors, restaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars openingindoors until :, and cinemas, theatres, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls reopening.It comes after the Covid- alert level in the UK was downgraded from Level  to Level  after a ldquoconsistent fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK put it downto the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.This means that the epidemic is in general circulation, but transmission of the virus is no longer deemed to be high or rising exponentially.It comes as experts said that the nation is in a ldquostrong position to press ahead with the easing of coronavirus restrictions.Nicola Sturgeoned to work at Bute House in Edinburgh on Sunday after her election victory.She told the BBCrsquos The Andrew Marr Show she would be meeting clinical advisers over the next day.She added: ldquoWe have a Covid review on Tuesday where we will set out the final decisions for the next easing of restrictions scheduled for May .The country is due to move down from Level  to Level  of restrictions on this date.Up to four people from two households can socialise indoors in a private home in Level .Pubs can sell alcohol indoors and cinemas, theatres, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls can open.However, there are still many areas still expected to remain closed in Level .Soft play, funfairs, indoor bowling, snooker pool halls and nightclubs are still not permitted to open in Level , according to current guidelines.Health authorities in the Moray are currently dealing with ldquouncontrolled, sustained community transmission of Covid-, with current restrictions failing to contain the spread.Latest statistics show Moray had . cases per , people in the seven days to May , signicantly higher than the rate in the rest of the country.Linda Bauld, professor of public health at the University of Edinburgh, warned that Moray may be in a dferent position from the rest of the country, with . cases per , in the seven days to May .She told BBC Good Morning Scotland: ldquoFrom what I understand from NHS Grampian colleagues this is not a specic outbreak as in a factory or another workplace, it is community transmission,  cases per ,, the R number is about . so people will recognise that meansyou have  people who are infected they could potentially pass it on to up to  so thatrsquos very serious.ldquoI think whatrsquos happened is wersquove still got a very transmissible virus, once you have clusters it does spread and it does seem to be in that local area, so I was particularly pleased to see two things ndash the first was opening of more testing sites in Moray and also giving good advice to people about the types of tests they can request based on symptoms or none, and the acceleration of that vaccine programme with invitations now being offered to younger adults more rapidly than where in Scotland.ldquoSo I really hope the situation stabilises. Only nine cases yesterday, letrsquos hope it continues to decline, otherwise there is a real risk that Moray will, as we feared, be one area which might have to delay its easing a little bit just at this crucial time when the rest of the country is moving into that next stage.The First Ministeris expected toaddress the nationjust after pm.Coverage will be screened live on theScottish Governments twitter account.It will also be broadcastlive on BBC One Scotland and iPlayer.

title: turning-tide-scotlands-waders
story: They are an iconic feature of our coastline and estuaries and their long-legged and long-billedsilhouettes appear too on lochsand lagoons, but the waders that are so much a part of our landscape are in dire trouble.In recent years populations of curlew and lapwing have collapsed, down % and % on what they once were, and oystercatchers too are struggling, with a third less of these beautul birds being recorded around our shores.Shting weather patterns and changing agricultural practices have been identied as some of the reasons why these birds are now failing to thrive but it is only in recent years that the full extent of the problem has been highlighted.Now urgent steps are being taken to reverse these population declines with Working for Waders, an initiative that brings together not just many dferent organisations and government bodies but also iniduals including farmers, crofters and land managers who all have a signicant role to play in turning the tide in favour of waders.Jessica Findlay is a Wildle Management Officer with NatureScot, one of the organisations involved in the initiative. She says that the last  years have seen numbers fall, with the most rapid declines being recorded in the last decade.ldquoNot everyone is aware of how badly populations have been affected, she says.ldquoIn some areas it still looks asthere are thousands of birds, while in other places they have all but disappeared.The first step to tackling the issue is raising awareness of the problem amongst those who can help to fix it and that means working with rural communities to change the timings of, amongst other things, grass cutting regimes.ldquoWithout the sort of cover that they get from long grass the birds are much more at risk from predators, says Jessica.Other steps include not rolling fields in spring, so that nests are not destroyed.Changing practices is not always straightforward but Jessica says she has been delighted by levels of engagement amongst farmers, including making lsquoscrapesrsquo ndash shallow ponds that are dug out by a digger and remain damp all year round, allowing insects to breed and offering feed for waders.Being able to offer small grants to help with this kind of work has proved to be very useful and other habitat management work includes cutting rushes and carrying out pest control.The public too, says Jessica, have a part to play by keeping dogs under control and Working for Waders is reinforcing the Access Code through promoting local signage that explains the breeding season of the birds and what dog owners can do to protect nests and chicks.ldquoOystercatchers, like all waders, nest on the ground which is why keeping dogs away from them during nesting time is so important.Some waders, including GoldenPlovers, make the journey to Scotland every summer, heading for moorlands to breed before flying back again before winter sets in.Redshanks, meanwhile, can be found around remote streams and wetlands, although these are getting harder to spot with their numbers declining % in  years.NatureScot, Scotlandrsquos Rural College, the RSPB, the British Trust for Ornithology, the James Hutton Institute, the Game and Wildle Conservation Trust and others have all joined forces in Working for Waders to put in place additional measures that they hope will help to improve the chances of the birds.This way of working follows the recently adopted Shared Approach to Wildle Management a collaborative model which brings all sorts of people together to develop action.Working for Waders is also open to ordinary members of the public to share their knowledge and enthusiasm to help tackle the decline of wading birds across Scotland. And the project, which was launched in , is continuing to capture the imagination of increasing numbers of people who have a shared interest in ensuring that the distinctive cry of the lapwing and the lonely call of the curlew donrsquot disappear from these shores.Just recently Working For Waders received a generous donation that allowed it to buy  trail cameras that are helping its members to understand the successes and failures of the waders across Scotland.These cameras have been distributed to farms across the country including the Isle of Skye, Speyside, Galloway and the Borders ndash all of them once home to large populations of waders.These cameras will be used to monitor what will hopefully be successful breeding seasons and help to inform watchers about the problems faced by these birds as part of a citizen science project that could make a positive impact on the future of some of Scotlandrsquos most important bird species.For more information visit: www.workingforwadersThis article is brought to you in association with NatureScot.

title: cabinet-office-minister-michael-gove-refuses-rule-legal-action-indyref2
story: The Cabinet Office minister, who is in Scotland this week, twice refused to give a straight answer on the point in a briefing with journalists.On Sunday, Mr Gove gave a series of ambiguous answers to the question on TV shows, saying he didnrsquot want to discuss the possibility of a Supreme Court challenge.Asked point blank todayhe was ruling out a challenge, he dismissed the issue as ldquotheorising and ldquoabstract debate and tried to change the subject, but did not deny it was a possibility.After the SNP won a landslide fourth term in last weekrsquos Holyrood election, Nicola Sturgeon said she would press ahead with Indyref when the Covid pandemic allowed.The First Minister has said she wants the vote by , thenindependence in .In a phone call with Mr Johnson on Sunday, she told the Prime Minister another referendum was now ldquoa matter of when not , despite his previous refusal to allow it.Asked about the FMs remark, Mr Gove said: ldquoOur focus is purely and principally on recovery at the moment. So of course there is a conversation about the constitution that some people will want to have.ldquoBut we think that is a distraction from the urgent need to make sure that we deal with backlog in NHS waiting lists, that we work together on economic recovery overall and that we also learn from each other when it comes to public sector recovery as well, whether it is in education or criminal justice.:Gordon Brown launches pro-Union campaign aimed at middle ScotlandThe Tory MP continued: ldquoPolitics is the language of priorities, our priority is to make sure we work with others on recovery at this moment.ldquoIt is not a conversation we believe is right to have at this moment, because it can only be a ersion of energy and attention at a time when there are far more pressing issues.Ms Sturgeon has said thatMr Johnson refuses to grant Holyrood the powers needed to hold a legally watertight referendum, the pro-independence parliament wouldpass its own Bill regardless, efectively daring Mr Johnson to challenge it at the UK Supreme Court.Asked specicallythe UK Government would take legal actionin such circumstances, Mr Gove would only say: ldquoIrsquom not getting into the whole question of court and litigation and all the rest of it, becausewe start theorising in the area then we are sucking oxygen out of the room when we should all be concentrating on recovery.ldquoOther people I am sure will want to speculate or theorise about these questions, but to my mind every second spent asking questions about the Supreme Court is a second wasted when it comes to concentrating on the issues in hand.:Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross says SNPs proposed Indyref Bill is a non-starterPressed again for a yes or no answer, he said: ldquoAs I say, Irsquom not thinking about it. Irsquom not going there."Wersquore concentrating on recovery in the NHS, recovery in the economy, recovery in education, recovery in the criminal justice system. That is our focus.Mr Gove even refused to saya party ought todeliver its manesto pledgesit had the votes to do so.He was asked: ldquoIf a political party wins an election, does that give it a mandate to implement its manesto in government, provided it ghets the votes Mr Gove replied: ldquoI think all political parties will want to reflect at this time on the campaign thatrsquos just been run and the priorities that the public sent them to office to fulfil.ldquoI think the critical things is, as the First Minister herself said, her aim, her principal aim was to amke sure we had and effective recovery from Covid.ldquoNicola said, when yoursquore thinking who you should vote for, you should be thinking about which first minister you want to carry on with continuity of recovery work, and that was her principal message and of course we respect that.After it was pointed out that wasnrsquot an answer to the question, and it was put to him a second time, Mr Gove again failed to answer it.He said: ldquoIrsquom sure that the First Minister will put propositions to the Scottish Parliament and the Scottish Parliament will have a chance to reflect on any propositions she puts.ldquoBut I respect the fact that she said her focus was on the recovery and I think thatrsquos the right focus.Earlier, Deputy First Minister John Swinney said Indyref shoudl go ahead when coronavirus is suppressed and ldquostable.:Salmond says Alba is home for lost souls of the Yes movementHe told BBC Radio Scotland: ldquoWe judge it by a combination of things ndash the actions that wersquove got to take to suppress the prevalence of the virus, and to make sure that we are in a stable position.ldquoSecondly, that we are able to sustain that position to make sure that wersquove got the necessary infrastructure in place to ensure that the virus is suppressed.ldquoIf the pandemic meets those tests, then obviously we are able to consider the whole question of the timing of the referendum on independence.Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross said the SNP should focus on the pandemic and delivering manesto pledges ldquowithin the remit of the Scottish Parliament, not Indyref.He said another referendum would create ldquouncertainty and ision all over again.

title: scottish-ballet-global-call-young-people-part-safe-festival
story: The initiative is part of Scottish Balletrsquos digital festival Safe to Be Me  - a celebration of ersity - which launches today, May .The festival follows the success of the companyrsquos pioneering schools programme and will be running through the month.The director of engagement at Scottish Ballet, Catherine Cassidy, said: ldquoWe have been humbled to see the direct impact that Safe to Be Me has had in schools and hope that, by moving and expanding the programme online, that the Festival will continue to use creative and critical thinking to promote acceptance and respect, and celebrate ersity.It will see Scottish Ballet engage with young people aged  to , to deliver a number of dance sessions, inspirational talks, and multi-artform workshops.:How women are taking a stand against sexualised sports kitsThe company will work directly with schools and community groups across Scotland to explore issues of ableism, bigotry, family ersity, homophobia, racism, and transphobia.The CEO artistic director of Scottish Ballet, Christopher Hampson, said: lsquoAt Scottish Ballet, we want to bring the benefits of dance to everyone and are excited that more people will have the opportunity to connect with the core values of Safe to Be Me by presenting it as a digital festival this year.ldquoAs a company, we are committed to engaging with people from all backgrounds using dance and movement as a tool to promote, understand and celebrate equality, ersity and inclusion across communities.rsquoThe festival will also present opportunity for international engagement.The programme isdesigned in line with key Scottish Government targets to address bullying, discrimination, and prejudice.:Save our Glasgow Clan petition nears , signaturesSince , Safe to Be Me has successfully been delivered to over  young people to empower and support them to help them feel safe and confident in who they are.This yearrsquos festival has been programmed in consultation with Conyach, Edinburgh International Festival, Intercultural Youth Scotland , LGBT Youth Scotland, and Sparkle ndash the national transgender charity.The founder and director of IYS, Khaleda Noon, said: ldquoScottish Ballets Safe to Be Me Festival gives young people a great opportunity to create and express themselves, providing them a  to create awareness and to showcase their talent in music, dance and film."You can find out more here.

title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: covid 19 vaccinations open for 18 to 29 year olds
story: coronavirusCOVID- vaccinations to open for  to -year-oldsMay ,  at : pmNHS Orkney has today confirmed that those aged  to  will be offered their first COVID- vaccination appointments at The Balfour, starting this month.The dates for these will be Saturday, May  Sunday, May  and Saturday, June . Letters will be sent out to these patients in the week commencing Monday, May  detailing when to attend for their vaccine.Letters are also being sent out this week to all patients aged  to  who have not yet had a first vaccine, inviting them to phone the vaccination centre to book in for this. The telephone number for the vaccination centre is   .Maureen Firth, NHS Orkney head of primacy care services, said: #We will be sending out further letters towards the end of next week to all patients who attended the Pickaquoy Centre for their first vaccine.#These letters will detail where patients should go to get their second vaccine. These vaccines will be given at the Balfour and the Kirkwall Vaccination Centre so, please read your letter carefully to know where to go.Ms Firth also revealed that: #we are due to vaccinate in the region of , patients during May. #We would therefore please ask that you attend at the time you are given unless you have an urgent reason to ask for this to be rescheduled. This will make our logistics and planning so much easier.#Thank you so much for your support during this vaccination programme, it has been much appreciated.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: feline finds fame after election count invasion
story: The owner of a cat who had to be ejected from the Orkney election count has shared her surprise after her favourite found national fame.Hannah Ker from Kirkwall was in stitches after spotting footage of her tortoiseshell Lola on both local and national news.The moggy made a surprise entrance at the Pickaquoy Centre arena, this morning, much to the amusement of count staff.After a quick wander to check that counting procedures were up to scratch, Lola was soon escorted from the premises.It wasn’t long before footage of the cat’s unexpected visit appeared on the national news, amid more standard coverage of the elections. Other news outlets soon picked up the story, while local commentators suggested that the cat might make a “purrrfect” late entry candidate.“We often wonder what Lola gets up to when we are working so we couldn’t believe our surprise when we seen her on the national news,” Miss Ker told The Orcadian.”She has always been such a friendly cat so it was no surprise she was away making new friends.“We always knew our little Lola would be destined for big things.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: electionHighlands and Islands list MSPs declaredMay ,  at : pm vw, px"  Four Conservatives will represent the Highlands and Islands region in the Scottish Parliament, alongside one MSPs each from the SNP, the Greens and Labour.The result for the region was officially declared this afternoon, Saturday.MSPs elected to the Highlands and Islands region include Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party leader Douglas Ross. He will be joined by his tory colleagues Edward Mountain, Donald Cameron and Jamie Halcro Johnston.Mr Halcro Johnston, who hails from Orkney, was one of four Highlands and Islands list MSPs ed to their seat in this election.Representing the SNP for the Highlands and Islands will be Emma Roddick, while Rhoda Grant has been ed to her seat as a Labour MSP. title: navy divers to receive freedom of orkney honour
story: newsNavy ers to receive Freedom of Orkney honourMay ,  at : pm vw, px"  The Royal Navy Northern Diving Group will have the Freedom of Orkney bestowed upon them in recognition of the group#s historic connection in commemorating those lost in the sinking of the HMS Royal Oak.Every year, the ers change the White Ensign on the wreck of the Royal Oak which was torpedoed while at anchor in Scapa Flow on October , , with the loss of  lives.Due to COVID restrictions,  was the first year since the recovery of the ship#s bell in  that the northern ing group was not able to change the White Ensign and pay tribute to those who lost their lives.The group and its predecessors have also assisted in disposing of historic ordinances such as mines, torpedoes and grenades on  occasions, and have assisted authorities in a wide range of commemorations and events over the years.Those who have also received the Freedom of Orkney include artist Stanley Cursiter, writer Ernest Marwick, navy ship HMS Orkney, the Queen#s Own Highlanders, and most recently Dr John Rae.At a meeting of the full council today , Orkney Islands Council councillors approved to confer the honour upon the ing group.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: orkney music bank relaunches
story: A charity which aims to promote and preserve Orcadian traditional music officially relaunched this week.The Reel Le Foundation, which was set up by Jenner and Hazel Wrigley, has been rebranded as Orkney Music and Culturewith hopes to push forward with the charity’s orginal goal to remove barriers in accessing music tuition in the county.This relaunch comes after the sad demise of Kirkwall music school and cafe, The Reel — the foundation’s original home.Full story in The Orcadian, available online and in shops.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: phased reopening of bossack announced
story: With the grass-cutting season upon us, Orkney Islands Councilhas announced the phased reopening of the Bossack Household Waste Recycling Centre on Tuesday, May .Initially, the site will only be accepting garden waste, and while the opening days remain the same as pre-COVID-, the opening hours will be restricted slightly to am-noon, and pm-pmon Tuesdays to Fridays.In line with government restrictions, there will be traffic management controls on site to ensure physical distancing.Full details in The Orcadian, available now online and in shops.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: recovery is the number one priority for re elected orkney msp
story: Liam McArthur has said that Orkney#s recovery from the fallout of the COVID- pandemic will be his number one priority as he enters a new Scottish Parliamentary term.Mr McArthur told The Orcadian that he was delighted to retained his seat in Orkney, which he has served for the past  years.Asked about his key hopes for the next five years, the Scottish Liberal Democrat MSP said: #I think the unying thing I would like to see for Orkney, the Highlands and Islands and Scotland is a focus on recovery. That recovery will be dferent in dferent parts of the country.#I#ve said consistently throughout this campaign — and what Willie Rennie has been saying nationally — is that that focus on recovery has to be the number one priority.#Mr McArthur was ed to his seat with , of , votes.SNP candidate Robert Leslie came second in the race with a total of , votes.Sam Bown, of the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party received  votes.Scottish Labour candidate, Coilla Drake, gained  votes.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: can-expect-queens-speech
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.The Queen in the Houses of ParliamentThe Government will set out its legislative agenda for the new parliamentary session in the Queenrsquos Speech on Tuesday.These are the measures which have already been confirmed or are expected:ndash Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill. Ministers have confirmed they will bring back the bill ndash giving police in England and Wales greater powers to shut down protests ndash after it was shelved in the last session amid violent protests in some parts of the country.ndash Environment Bill. Also confirmed is the commitment to set new, legally-binding environmental targets in the run-up to the international Cop climate change summit in Glasgow at the end of year. vw,vw,px, px"An easing of planning rules is expected in an attempt to boost housebuilding ndash Adult social care. Boris Johnson promised reform when he entered Downing Street in  but the Government has yet to put forward proposals. However, Michael Gove insisted at the weekend that there will be a specic plan which will be ldquoheading for the statute books by the end of the year.ndash A Health and Care Bill is expected to implement planned changes to the the structure of NHS England.ndash A planning bill is expected to ease controls in England as part of a concerted drive to boost housebuilding.ndash A Skills and Post- Education Billis expected as part of the Governmentrsquos ldquolevelling up agenda with the promise of a ldquoletime skills guarantee.ndash A Sovereign Borders Bill is expected to overhaul the asylum system in an attempt to deter migrants from crossing the Channel. vw,vw,px, px"New asylum rules are expected in an attempt to deter migrants crossing the Channel ndash An Elections Integrity Bill is expected to require voters to produce proof of their identity when voting in elections.ndash Fixed-term Parliaments Act repeal. Ministers have said they will scrap the  legislation brought in by the former coalition government and restore the prerogative power to call early general elections.ndash A Building Safety Bill is expected to bring in a new system of safety regulations and inspections for buildings under construction in the wake of the Grenfell Tower fire.ndash Legislation is expected to limit future prosecutions of British soldiers who served in Northern Ireland during the Troubles. Reports suggest it may also cover paramilitaries.ndash AnAnimal Sentience Billwill give animals ldquowith a backbone the ldquoright to have their feelings recognised in law.ndash An Animals Abroad Bill is expected to ban the import of trophies from animal hunting while a Kept Animals Bill will stop live animal exports and ban families from keeping primates as pets.copy -. title: pm-defends-plan-require-id-vote-face-widespread-backlash
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Polling stationBoris Johnson has defended plans to require voters to prove their identity before casting ballots, despite condemnation from civil liberties groups and senior MPs on both sides of the Commons.The Prime Minister said on Monday that it was ldquocomplete nonsense to suggest he was trying to supress the votes of those who do not back the Tories by introducing the identication requirement.Downing Street insisted it was a ldquoreasonable approach and that .% of people in pilots requiring people to show photographic ID had managed to vote without dficulty.Mr Johnson said the move, to be included in the Queenrsquos Speech on Tuesday, is necessary to ldquoprotect democracy, but Tory former Cabinet minister David Davis said it was an ldquoilliberal solution for a non-existent problem."If Ministers had any intention of making our voting system fairer, they wouldnt be creating new barriers to voting, but focusing on making it easier for everyone to have an equal say in our democratic process."Libertys view on #VoterID plans## https:t.co oCtskBgmdash LibertyMay , Campaigners also warned that people without ID would be disenfranchised as a result of the move, especially those in marginalised groups.But askedhe was trying to limit votes for opposition parties, the Prime Minister told the Downing Street press conference: ldquoI would say that was complete nonsense and what we want to do is to protect democracy, the transparency and the integrity of the electoral process, and I donrsquot think itrsquos unreasonable to ask first-time voters to produce some evidence of identity.The Tory  manesto committed to introducing the requirement to produce identication in order to vote at a polling station.But Mr Davis told The Independent: ldquoItrsquos yet another unnecessary ID card approach from the Governmenthellip Therersquos no evidence that Irsquom aware of that there is a problem with voter fraud at polling stations.Shadow democracy minister Cat Smith said . million voters did not have photographic ID and the policy would ldquoput up obstacles for poorer voters.ldquoThe chances are we all know someone without photo ID, maybe itrsquos your nan, your son, your mate from the football  Donrsquot have a driving licence, donrsquot travel abroad  she added.Jess Garland, director of policy and research at the Electoral Reform Society, said: ldquoDavid Davis is right, this policy is a solution in search of a problem.We already have low turn out in elections and millions of people lack photo ID. Faced with having to take time off work to attend a local council office and request a special letter to let them vote, people will simply stay at home.mdash Electoral Reform SocietyMay , ldquoVoting is safe and secure in the UK, meaning this policy is just an unnecessary barrier to democratic participation. Ministers need to listen to these concerns and drop these costly plans.ldquoMillions of people lack photo ID in this country. These proposals will make it harder to vote for huge numbers of voters, locking ordinary people out of our democracy and unfairly discriminating against those who lack ID.Sam Grant, head of policy and campaigns at Liberty, said: ldquoMillions of people in the UK donrsquot have photo ID, and the vast majority of them come from communities that are already marginalised and under-represented by our political system.ldquoMeanwhile the Governmentrsquos own findings show our current voting system is safe and secure. Instead of creating more barriers to voting, Ministers should focus on making it easier for everyone to vote, and ensuring we can all have an equal say in our democratic process.ldquoAs there is no justication for this threat to the right to vote, it feels like an opportunistic attack on the rights of some of the most marginalised people in society, a classic example of ruling through ision and distrust.Under the Governmentrsquos plans, rules will be tightened on absent voting and voter intimidation as the Government aims to ldquostamp out fraud.Measures will include a ban on postal vote harvesting by limiting the number of votes a person can hand in at a polling station on behalf of others.Voter intimidation is also expected to be listed as a form of undue influence in law, in order to prevent people from being coerced into giving up control over their vote.copy -. title: under 40s to be given pfizer vaccine following new advice
story: People in their thirties will receive the Pfizer vaccine for their first dose, following advice they should not be given AstraZeneca where possible.The new guidance has come from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation , which says that alternatives should be found for the under s.NHS Shetland has subsequently had a rethink how it will deliver vaccines to the younger age group.It says anyone in this group who has already received AstraZeneca will receive the same vaccine for their second dose.The JCVI advice changed after a review on extremely rare blood clot-related side effects.But NHS Shetland has stressed this does not mean AstraZeneca can not be used in this age group # only that an alternative is preferred.The JCVI had already changed the guidelines for the - age group.Interim director of public health Dr Susan Laidlaw said the risk of clotting complications in those under  who received AstraZeneca was very low.“The JCVI is clear that in the - group, any of the UK vaccines is better than no vaccine, unless there are specic medical contra-indications,# she said.#There may be some circumstances where NHS Shetland may still offer AstraZeneca because it is the only one that is practical under specic circumstances.”More than , first doses and , second doses have already been completed in Shetland with more than  people vaccinated at Gilbertson Park on Thursday...Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.Over s are being urged to contact NHS Shetlandthey wish to have a Covid jab.The Mousa Broch should now be within easy reach of visitors, thanks to a decision to restart runs of the Mousa boat. Covid- had played#More than  first doses of the Covid-  vaccine were administered in Shetland yesterday # the largest daily figure in weeks.Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: fishing industry call for panel to assess wild swings in catch advice
story: Scotland#s two largest fishing associations have urged Scottish ministers to form a special  to assess #wild swings# in catch advice.The Shetland Fishermen’s Associationand the Scottish White Fish Producers’ Associationwant an independent body to assess recommendations from the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea .SFA executive officer Simon Collins said it was essential that any catch advice was #informed by science#.#Unfortunately, the advice produced by ICES can turn out to be erroneous, resulting in unnecessary damage to the fishing industry and the communities that depend on it.#The associations argue that insufficient account is taken of the often “shaky foundations” on which ICES stock assessments are made, with most derived from computer models and complex mathematical algorithms.Mr Collins said that #vast swings# in stock advice can result from tweaks to these models, often to the #severe detriment# to local fishermen...Major figures in the local seafood industry have written to the SIC with concerns about laden oil tankers anchoring off the coast of the isles.Alison Kay skipper James Anderson is taking charge at the Shetland Fishermen#s Association. He replaces departing chairman Leslie Tait, who will move into a role#More than half of the fish and shellfish caught in Shetland waters is landed by EU fishing boats, while the local fleet gets less thanAlready a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: port looking ahead to better times having weathered worst of pandemic
story: Harbour traffic statistics have again highlighted the severe impact of the pandemic ndashthough bosses are working towards ldquobetter times ahead.The latest Lerrwick Port Authority figures for the first quarter of  show a decline in all sectors compared to the same period pre-lockdown.They are said to show the continuing severe effects Covid- and the oil industry slump on Shetlandrsquos economy.#The coming months should bring slight improvements in activity on the long haul to recovery.Vessel tonnage for the period, at ,, gross tonnes, dropped  per cent.shipping and an  percent decrease in fishing boats.Cargo was down per centat , tonnes, including drops of  per centin oil-related shipmentsand  per cent in roll-on roll-off ferry freight.Ferry passengers travelling between Lerwick, Aberdeen and Kirkwall, fell  per centto ,during the three months, due mainly to national lock-down during the period.There were no cruise ship passengers during the quarter which usually sees a gradual start to the season ndash yet to begin.The , boxes of whitefish landed at Lerwick fish market was downdown  per cent.In the pelagic sector, mackerel throughput fell  per cent.Capt. Grains added: ldquoThe UK governmentrsquos decision to allow cruise ships into English ports from th May will hopefully be followed soon by the Scottish government enabling resumption, giving us a part-season and helping rebuild Shetlandrsquos hard-hit tourism industry.ldquoThe recent opening up of UK internal travel should benefit ferry traffic and visiting pleasure craft.ldquoWhitefish landings have been showing signs of recovery and port-Brexit movement of seafood exports through the EU is slowly improving.ldquoThe offshore decommissioning market is promising and support for the renewable energy sector continues to increase...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. Before joining The Shetland Times, I was part of Archants Investigations Unit, reporting for titles across the group. When not at work, Im usually reading books, listening to records or walking around the countryside.Restore Scotland candidate Brian Nugent has criticised the First Minister#s comments on a fishing deal, which he claimed #betrayed a lack of knowledge# on theFishermen in Shetland today welcomed the rejection of a deal with Norway.The death of a Shetland fisherman has been highlighted in a new campaign on man overboard protection at sea.Seas near Shetland are reported to be teeming with oil-eating bacteria, which scientists say could help deal with future oil spills.Lerwick Port Authority has received a share of £. million towards work at the harbour.A seafood organisation has warned the Brexit red tape seen earlier this year could be the demise of small fishing businesses.
